title: 108_hr4684
content: The "Neighbors in Need Act" includes provisions for temporary extended unemployment compensation, reforms to the federal unemployment benefit system, and amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Title I of the "Neighbors in Need Act" includes a 2-year suspension of tax on unemployment compensation, state collection of Federal unemployment tax, and required distribution of State-specific information packets. Additionally, there is a program extension for states experiencing high unemployment. The Temporary Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 2002 is amended to include a program extension for states with high unemployment. States meeting specific criteria will make payments to eligible individuals during their period of unemployment. The Temporary Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 2002 is amended to include provisions for individuals in an extended benefit period or qualifying for temporary extended unemployment compensation benefits. The amount in an account under section 203(a) will be determined for this purpose. The Temporary Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 2002 is amended to include provisions for individuals in an extended benefit period or qualifying for temporary extended unemployment compensation benefits. Section 203(a) establishes an account for this purpose, with specific adjustments for individuals meeting exhaustion requirements during certain timeframes. The period of eligibility for individuals receiving benefits under the Temporary Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 2002 begins on the date of enactment and ends before the 12th week following. Temporary extended unemployment compensation will be payable to eligible individuals for weeks following the 12th week after enactment, but not beyond the 25th week. Technical amendments are made to the Temporary Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 2002. The text chunk discusses the amendment to the Social Security Act regarding the increase and decrease in earnings credited to state accounts based on meeting or failing to meet funding goals. The amendment to the Social Security Act adjusts earnings credited to state accounts based on meeting or failing to meet funding goals. If the average daily balance in a State account exceeds the funding goal, an interest premium is added, and if it is below the goal, an interest penalty is applied. The Secretary adjusts interest premiums based on funding goals. Interest penalties are applied if the State account balance is below the goal. The penalty cannot exceed $2,500,000 per quarter. Interest payments are calculated based on a formula for states with excess funds in their Unemployment Trust Fund accounts. The Secretary adjusts interest premiums based on funding goals, with penalties applied if State account balances fall below the goal. The penalty limit is $2,500,000 per quarter. Interest payments are calculated using a formula for states with excess funds in their Unemployment Trust Fund accounts. The funding goal is determined as the average of unemployment benefits paid by the State over the highest 3 years in a 20-year period. The text discusses adjustments to interest premiums based on funding goals in State accounts in the Unemployment Trust Fund. Amendments are made to the Social Security Act to determine interest rates on advances without considering interest premiums or penalties. Amendments are made to the Social Security Act to adjust interest premiums in State accounts in the Unemployment Trust Fund. The Secretary of Labor is required to report on funding sources for interest premiums under certain conditions. The effective date for these changes is after December 31, 2007. Amendments to the Social Security Act restrict interest-free advances to State accounts in the Unemployment Trust Fund to States meeting funding goals. The effective date for these changes is after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, there is a 2-year suspension of tax on unemployment compensation under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Section 301 suspends the tax on unemployment compensation for 2 years starting in 2004 or 2005. Section 302 addresses state collection of federal unemployment tax. At the election of a certified State, employers paying contributions into an unemployment fund must submit the tax to the State instead of the Secretary. Payment to the State is considered timely if made alongside contributions to the fund. The tax imposed by this chapter must be paid by the employer to the State instead of the Secretary, as per the certified State's election. The State must transmit the tax amount to the Secretary along with employer tax returns. Additional information may be required by the Secretary through regulations. Code is amended by striking the item relating to section 3311 and inserting new items. The amendments made by this section apply to calendar years beginning after December 31, 2004. Required distribution of state-specific information packets. SEC. 303 amends the Internal Revenue Code to require states to distribute State-specific information packets to explain unemployment insurance eligibility conditions. This amendment applies to certifications of States for 2005, with a deadline of July 1, 2006, for compliance if the state legislature does not meet in a regular session closing in 2005.
